title: Update OPRF_Finalize algorithm
body:
It is helpful in some applications to allow finalization over specific data. This change is based on the existing PR for protocol integrations and so needs to be merged into that branch before master.

Changes:
- Allows finalization over auxiliary data

title: Update batching section
body:
For #56:
- More specificity on rejection sampling
- Add batched unblinding algorithm

title: Allow specifying auxiliary data in OPRF_Finalize
body:
We should modify the OPRF_Finalize procedure to run:

```
dk = H_2(lbl, x .. N)
y = H_2(dk, aux)
```

where aux is arbitrary auxiliary data that is also stored by the client. This is closer to current implementations of the Privacy Pass protocol and likely to be useful in applications where there is a later redemption step that needs to be bound to specific request data.

title: Protocol integration suggestions
body:
Branch to be merged into alxdavids/sec-considerations branch as it depends on some changes in that branch.

Changes:
- Changes to some of the (V)OPRF functions
- Suggestions for implementing OPRF evaluation as part of wider protocol

@chris-wood are these recommendations for protocol integration helpful?

title: Better specification of batched DLEQ proof algorithm
body: We need to specify the random oracle instantiation in Section 6.3 more concretely.

title: Updated security considerations
body:
Intended to address #50 and #52. 

Changes:
- Discussion of Q-strong-DH oracle attacks and effects on OPRF security
- Updated ciphersuites with larger security parameters (> 128 bits of security)
- More discussion of cryptographic security reduction from [JKK14] for the construction that we give
- More detailed discussion of security/privacy implications arising from user segregation and key rotation

title: Protocol integration
body: We should add a section that discusses the OPRF API that should be used when using OPRFs as part of another protocol. We should present both descriptions and suggestions around how the functionality should be integrated.

title: Domain separation
body: We should add a section that provides clarity on the domain separation interface and how it is introduced to the OPRF.

title: Establish new ciphersuites
body:
Since OPRFs can be used to instantiate q-Strong-DH oracles, they are susceptible to attacks that reduce security by log_2(m), where m is the number of queries.

We should establish new ciphersuites that use underlying curves with > 128 bits of security (e.g. using Curve448) to protect against these attacks. Proposed ciphersuites:

P384:
```
## ECVOPRF-P384-HKDF-SHA512:

- GG: secp384r1 {{SEC2}}
- H_1: P384-SHA512-ICART-RO {{I-D.irtf-cfrg-hash-to-curve}}
  - label: voprf_h2c_p384
- H_2: SHA512
- H_3: SHA512
- H_4: SHA512
- H_5: HKDF-Expand-SHA512 {{RFC5869}}
```

Curve448:
```
## ECVOPRF-Curve448-HKDF-SHA512:

- GG: curve448 {{RFC7748}}
- H_1: curve448-SHA512-ICART-RO {{I-D.irtf-cfrg-hash-to-curve}}
  - label: voprf_h2c_c448
- H_2: SHA512
- H_3: SHA512
- H_4: SHA512
- H_5: HKDF-Expand-SHA512 {{RFC5869}}
```

P521:
```
## ECVOPRF-P521-HKDF-SHA512:

- GG: secp521r {{SEC2}}
- H_1: P521-SHA512-SSWU-RO {{I-D.irtf-cfrg-hash-to-curve}}
  - label: voprf_h2c_p521
- H_2: SHA512
- H_3: SHA512
- H_4: SHA512
- H_5: HKDF-Expand-SHA512 {{RFC5869}}
```

- OPRF evaluations for new ciphersuites
- DLEQ evaluations
- Batched DLEQ evaluations

- We need to discuss the effectiveness of using OPRFs as an oracle for producing q-Strong-DH samples
- Go into more depth on key rotation and how it can be used to prevent token hoarding
- Discuss the impact on client privacy from having small or segregated user bases

title: Fix OPRF password applications
body:
From Hugo:
```
   Examples of such password checkers already exist, for example:
   [JKKX16], [JKK14] and [SJKS17].

> The above papers do not propose a use for password checker. They do present
> some important applications of OPRFs in the password domain: password-protected
> storage [JKK14,JKKX16] and a password manager that secures passwords against 
> offline dictionary attacks even when the password store is compromised [SJKS17].

> You may also want to note the OPRF functions presented here admit very
> efficient threshold schemes where the key is shared between n servers, 
> t of which need to be broken into to compromise the OPRF, and where the key 
> never exists in a single place, neither during generation nor for computing 
> the OPRF function [JKKX17].
> [JKKX17] TOPPSS: Cost-minimal Password-Protected Secret Sharing based on 
> Threshold OPRF https://eprint.iacr.org/2017/363.pdf
```

title: Replace PRNG with RO for batched proof
body:
As Hugo notes:
```
 2. d1,...dn <- PRNG(seed,salt,info,n)

> PRNGs inputs are just a seed, usually a secret one. There are no guarantees
> about the pseudorandomness of the output for a public seed. Additional items
> such as salt, info, n, are not accommodated at all in a PRNG. You could put
> these under H_4 or use a (variable-length output) PRF instead of PRNG.
> But also in the PRF case, non-secret key does not guarantee pseudorandomness.
> What you seem to need is a RO which on inputs G,Y,[Mi,Zi],salt,info,n outputs 
> d1,...dn (is there a proof that batching is secure when both parties derive d_i
> using a RO?)

> Btw, independently of the above issues, if you let the prover choose the salt,
> this can help him (at least in theory) to cheat - i.e., finding a set of
> "misleading"  d's.
```
I think it will be easiest to introduce an additional RO `H_4` that handles the generation of `d1,...,d4` here.

We would also need to clarify the best instantiations for doing this, it may be that we stick with SHAKE-SHA256 and HKDF-Expand-SHA256 (this should also be clarified as we currently just say HKDF-256). The notion of the `salt` should be replaced with a domain separation label.

title: Minor comments from Hugo
body:
Fix the following:
```
        Verifier              Prover
     ------------------------------------
        r <-$ GG

> r is chosen randomly from GF(p) not GG

        M = rH_1(x)
                      M
                   ------->
                              Z = kM
                              [D = DLEQ_Generate(k,G,Y,M,Z)]
                     Z[,D]
                   <-------
       [b = DLEQ_Verify(G,Y,M,Z,D)]
       N = Zr^(-1)

 > It may be a good idea to say explicitly that the inverse of r is modulo the
 > group order p.
```
```
  l: Some suitable choice of key-length (e.g. as described in {{NIST}}).

> {{NIST}} should be formatted as [ ]
```
```
   Steps:

    1. N := (1/r)Z

> It was r^(-1) before - use same notation everwhere
```
```
   If the client preprocesses values of the form rG, then computing

> you don't need to pre-process values rG to get the computational advantage.
> This comes from the cost of a fixed-base vs variable base exponentiation.
> The only thing you need to pre-process is some tables for the specific G
> (this applies to the public key if you have it and use it often).
```
```
    1. A' := (sG + cY)
    2. B' := (sM + cZ)
    3. c' <- H_3(G,Y,M,Z,A',B')
    4. Output c == c'

> It may be prudent remarking that, as in the case of Schnorr/(EC)DSA, revealing
> or reusing r lead to the leakage of the secret OPRF key k.
```
```
   o  Proof verification is much more efficient, from 4m modular

> I guess this should be 4n?

      exponentiations to 2n+4.
```
```
Moreover, it each key should be generated from a source of
> remove 'it'
   safe, cryptographic randomness.

   Another critical aspect of this protocol is reliance on
> Replace "Another" with "A" (rotation of k is good but not critical in general)
```
```
   VOPRF sessions for a given user and thus compromises their privacy.

> compromise (not compromises)
```
```
   This VOPRF protocol is used by Privacy Pass system 
> add reference here
```
```
   [SJKS17]   "SPHINX, A Password Store that Perfectly Hides from
              Itself", n.d.,
              <http://webee.technion.ac.il/%7Ehugo/sphinx.pdf>.
> Replace with this URL:
> https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/695.pdf
```

title: OPRF_Sign -> OPRF_Eval
body:
It may be more accurate to replace "signing" terminology with "evaluation". Signing is asymmetric terminology and so this may be confusing, since (V)OPRFs are essentially symmetric primitives.

From Hugo:

```
   o  OPRF_Sign(k,M,h): Sign input M using secret key k to produce Z,
      the input h is optional and equal to the cofactor of an elliptic
      curve.  If h is not provided then it defaults to 1.

> Using "Sign" may be confusing, especially in the non-verifiable OPRFs.
> Maybe OPRF_Eval?  Signer/Verifier would be Server/Client (one can still 
> use signer/verifier in the context of V-OPRF).
```

title: Clarify generator description
body: We should clarify whether the generator `G` is fixed as part of the parameters of the group `GG`, or whether it is sampled randomly is specified as part of the OPRFs parameters. I would prefer the first.

title: Clean up security properties for OPRF
body:
The pseudorandomness of the function dictates that it is unlinkable and non-malleable, so we can remove these properties. There are some other things that Hugo brought up:

```
   o  The output distribution of y = F(k, x) is indistinguishable from
      the uniform distribution in the domain of the function F.

> domain -> range

> It is more general and "more correct" to define PRF as in the introduction
> "F is pseudorandom if the output y = F(k, x) is indistinguishable from
> uniformly sampling any element in F's range for random choice of k."
> From this all the properties you list follow (including the "additional ones")
```

```
   Additionally, we require the following additional properties:

> additional twice
```

```
   o  Oblivious: P must learn nothing about V's input, and V must learn
      nothing about P's private key.

> Oblivious should include also "P learns nothing about the output of the
> function". Formally, this is redundant but it is a very important consequence
> of the definition and it is better to say it explicitly.
```

```
   o  Verifiable: V must only complete execution of the protocol if it
      can successfully assert that P used its secret key k.

> "used its key" is a bit too vague. Maybe: if it can successfully assert that
> the OPRF output V computes is correct with respect to the OPRF key k held by
> P.
```

```
   In practice, the notion of verifiability requires that P commits to
   the key k before the actual protocol execution takes place.  Then V
   verifies that P has used k in the protocol using this commitment.

> We could add: Below we will refer to this commitment to k as a "public key".
```

title: Clarify RSA blind signature scheme in intro
body:
From Hugo:

```
> This schemes does not work with RSA. You cannot compute the inverse of r
> without knowing the factorization of N. Chaum's scheme uses multiplicative
> blinding (see my comments on this issue).  
```

Maybe we should just remove this section, it's probably not that helpful anyway?

title: Correct sections
body: Hugo noted that some of the Sections are incorrectly labelled.

title: Certified public key
body:
In our protocol, the public key is `(G, Y)` where `Y = kG` for the Server's key `k`.

From Hugo:

```
The reason is that when Y is not certified (namely, the client gets it from the
server but cannot verify it - as in OPAQUE settings where the client does not
store Y), there are some "attacks" that we have identified that do not seem to
have a practical effect but suffice to show that the OPRF with additive blinding
does not satisfy our UC definition of OPRF (this is noted in the OPAQUE paper). 
We are working on this now to show that one can weaken the UC functionality to
accept the additive blinding as secure and showing that this definition suffices
for OPAQUE. But we don't have the full results yet. The reason I prefer NOT to
include Y under the hash is that if you do multiplicative blinding in the
non-verifiable case then you don't need Y at all, and if you are in a verifiable
case with certified Y then the "attack" does not work. Still, for the
non-certified Y case and additive blinding, the issue is not fully resolved. For
OPAQUE I was hoping that by the time we standardize on it, we will have a better
understanding of this issue and will be able to eliminate Y under the hash but
now it is a bit premature to have 100% confidence.
```

So I think the way to resolve this is to either specify that `Y` is certified in the additive case, or we could include `Y` in the hash (i.e. compute `H(x,Y,H1(x)^k)`). It's true that we don't need to do this in the multiplicative case so maybe including in the hash is overkill, and we should just go with certification?

@chris-wood for opinion.

title: Replace additive vs multiplicative blinding terminology
body:
From Hugo:
```
A note on terminology: additive vs multiplicative is problematic since in the
case of multiplicative notation this becomes multiplicative vs exponential with
multiplicative playing two different meanings. I thought maybe calling them
Fixed-base blinding (FBB) vs Variable-base blinding (VBB).
```
i.e. we should replace additive blinding with FBB, and multiplicative with VBB.

title: nit on reduction modulo p
body:
At section 5.1.  DLEQ_Generate
~~~
4. s := (r - ck) (mod p)  
~~~
It must be reduced modulo the order of the curve.

title: DLEQ_Generate should take the secret key as an input
Add batched proofs for multiple client inputs
body: The draft currently only covers DLEQ proof generation for input query from the client. It would be good to integrate the batching mechanism that we use in Privacy Pass when the client makes n>1 input queries.

title: Making verifiability optional
body:
@chris-wood I spoke to Hugo Krawczyk at RWC and he mentioned being more general in this draft so that we cover OPRFs as well as VOPRFs (i.e. make verifiability optional). This would allow us to cover additional use-cases such as that of OPAQUE (https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/163.pdf) and SPHINCS (https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/695.pdf). It may also help to differentiate the techniques that we use from VRFs without obliviousness.

What do you think? I would be happy to write up the necessary changes.

title: ECVOPRF->VOPRF
body: Related to #13

title: Change "curve" to "prime-order group"
body:
The VOPRF is generic and can be designed in any prime-order group so we should probably refer to it as such. We can then talk specifically about the various instantiations of prime-order groups including elliptic curves.

@chris-wood If you're happy with this, then I am happy to make the change.

title: Using SWU encoding for hash-to-curve
body: Not an expert with hashing to curves but it seems like the SWU encoding seems to work for P-256, so shall we go with that?  We already have noted with privacy pass that we should look to move towards this method of encoding so it seems to fit well.

title: Add parameter commitment and application information.
Add a section on use cases
Expand test vectors with DLEQ proof outputs
Add "parameter commitment" support
body:
In some cases, it may be desirable for P to force V to only redeem its PRF value for specific set of "parameters." For example, imagine P and V could use the PRF output to derive an encryption key for encrypting data to the server, though V is free to use whatever encryption algorithm it likes. V tells P which algorithm it's using in its redemption+data message to P. Currently, P cannot restrict the algorithm V uses since the only thing P commits to is the keying material during the VOPRF protocol. 

One way to address this problem is as follows. Let _params_ be the parameters that P wishes V to use when redeeming its PRF value. (In the example above, it might be a canonical representation of the encryption algorithm cipher suite.) When multiplying V's blinded message M by its scalar, P also mixes in t = H(_params_ || k2), where k2 is another secret scalar != k, and H is a full-domain hash function that maps to curve base field (e.g., Z_p). The resulting blinded and "signed" message is then Z = tkM = rkrX. 

When redeeming the PRF value, V supplies the PRF input *and* _params_. P can then recompute t as above and mix it into the computation. Moreover, since t is computed by appending a secret to the parameters and hashing the result, V cannot remove it from Z without knowledge of k2.

title: Clean up DLEQ notation, adopt that of PrivacyPass
body:
r & \gets \mathbb{Z}_p \\
A &= rG \\
B &= rM \\
c &= H(G,Y,Z,A,B) \\
s &= (r - ck) (\text{mod} p) \\
& \mathsf{Output } \; (c, s) 


A' &= sG + cY \\
B' &= sM + cZ \\
c' &= H(G,Y,Z,A',B') \\
& \mathsf{Output } \; c == c'

\log_G(Y) =? \log_M(Z)
Y = kG, Z = kM

\mathsf{DLEQVerify}(G, Y, M, Z, (c, s))

\mathsf{DLEQGenerate}(G, Y, M, Z)

title: add contributor

title: Some comments on first look
body:
I have made some small changes and also some comments (prefaced with ALEX:). I plan to have a more detailed run-through soon, particularly with the algorithmic stuff to make sure the inputs/outputs are consistent throughout. Maybe the best thing would be to respond to the comments on here and then I can change/not change accordingly?

I'm not sure of the process for IETF drafts but I guess there will need to be some justification of the security properties that are proposed. I guess proofs might be a stretch but it might be possible to get some intuition down, what do you think?

Also, were there any TODOs that you were considering before you went ahead with submission?

(I tried make-ing the changes but it was complaining about the {{H2c}} reference?)
